parts:
### Recap of the first-order balance  
Along Lagrangian trajectories we had

\[
\frac{\mathrm D}{\mathrm Dt}\log\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho}\Bigr)
\;\approx\;
\varepsilon(t)\,e^{-\gamma t},\qquad
\gamma:=2\lambda_{\min}^{\infty}+\Sigma^{\infty}\; (>0\ \text{or}\ <0 \text{depending on the flow}),
\tag{1}
\]

so the whole game is to pick a strictly positive, *small* function  
\(\varepsilon(t)\) that produces whatever time–profile you want on the right-hand side.

---

## 1 One expression, two regimes

Write

\[
\varepsilon(t)=c(t)\,e^{\gamma t},
\tag{2}
\]

with \(c(t)\) still to be chosen.  Then (1) simply becomes

\[
\frac{\mathrm D}{\mathrm Dt}\log(\rho_\varepsilon/\rho)
\;\approx\;
c(t).
\tag{3}
\]

Everything now hinges on how you let \(c(t)\) depend on \(t\).

---

## 2 *Finite*-time control (target time \(T\))

Suppose you want \(\log(\rho_\varepsilon/\rho)\) to remain bounded up to a **large but finite** horizon \(T\).  
A convenient choice is

\[
c(t)=\frac{\kappa}{(T-t)^{1+\delta}},\qquad
0<\delta<1,\;\kappa=O(1),
\tag{4}
\]

because

\[
\int_{0}^{T^-} \frac{\kappa}{(T-\tau)^{1+\delta}}\,\mathrm d\tau
=\frac{\kappa}{\delta}\,<\infty .
\]

In words:  
*blow \(c(t)\) up just fast enough near \(T\) to squeeze the ratio to your prescribed value, yet still keep the integral finite.*

For \(t\ll T\) we then have \(c(t)\propto T^{-1-\delta}\), so \(c(t)\) is small and the expansion (1) remains self-consistent.

---

## 3 Long-time (asymptotic) control

If instead you care about the **tail** \(t\to\infty\) and you want  
\(\log(\rho_\varepsilon/\rho)\) to converge there, you must arrange

\[
\int^{\infty} c(t)\,\mathrm dt<\infty \;\Longleftrightarrow\;
c(t)=O\!\bigl(t^{-1-\delta}\bigr)\quad(\delta>0).
\tag{5}
\]

The simplest concrete options are

\[
c(t)=\frac{\kappa}{t^{1+\delta}}
\quad\text{(integrable, convergent ratio)},
\qquad
\text{or}\qquad
c(t)=\frac{\kappa}{t}
\quad\text{(borderline, logarithmic divergence)}.
\tag{6}
\]

> **Rule of thumb**  
> *Pick \(c(t)\) so that*  
> \(\displaystyle\int_{t_0}^{\infty} c(t)\,\mathrm dt\)  
> *either converges (finite limit) or diverges only as slowly as you are willing to tolerate.*

---

## 4 Why the same expression covers both cases

* Put \(c(t)=t\) in (2).  Then  
  \(\varepsilon(t)=t\,e^{\gamma t}\) and (3) gives a **constant** rate \(c(t)\sim t\).  
  Integrating from \(0\) to a *finite* \(T\) gives \(\tfrac12 T^{2}\): acceptable if \(T\) itself is your target time; meaningless if \(T\to\infty\).

* Put \(c(t)=\text{const}\).  Now  
  \(\frac{\mathrm D}{\mathrm Dt}\log(\rho_\varepsilon/\rho)\) decays as \(1/t\) (because the *constant* is divided by the linear time that emerges when you impose \(c(t)=\kappa t^{-1}\)).  Integrating to infinity yields a log divergence—still finite over any bounded interval but unbounded as \(t\to\infty\).

Thus the *same functional template* (2) works in both regimes; you simply choose:

| **Goal** | **Time window** | **Pick \(c(t)\)** | **Behaviour of the ratio** |
|----------|-----------------|-------------------|----------------------------|
| Control at a prescribed horizon \(T\) | \(0\le t<T\) | \(c(t)\) blowing up like \((T-t)^{-1-\delta}\) (4) | Finite, matches the required value at \(T\) |
| Gentle decay / convergence for large \(t\) | \(t\to\infty\) | \(c(t)\sim t^{-1-\delta}\) with \(\delta>0\) (5–6) | Finite limit (or, with \(\delta=0\), log divergence) |

---

## 5 Self-consistency (smallness of \(\varepsilon\))

Because \(\varepsilon(t)=c(t)e^{\gamma t}\),

* **If \(\gamma<0\)** (typical for dissipative systems), exponential decay dominates every algebraic choice of \(c(t)\); \(\varepsilon(t)\)\! stays *small for all time*, so the expansion behind (1) is safe.

* **If \(\gamma>0\)** (weakly expanding volume), you must restrict your construction to times \(t\) such that \(c(t)e^{\gamma t}\ll1\).  That still leaves a wide window, but you cannot push the theory to arbitrary \(t\).

---

### Bottom line

* Yes, you **do** pick different \(c(t)\)—hence different \(\varepsilon(t)\)—depending on **where** you want control (finite horizon versus asymptotic tail).  
* In practice just substitute \(c(t)\) of your choice into (2); then (3) gives the instantaneous rate and its integral tells you exactly how the ratio behaves.

parts:
Yes — to first order in \(\varepsilon\) you can replace the denominator \(\rho_\varepsilon\) by the unsmoothed \(\rho\) without altering any \(O(\varepsilon)\)-level terms.

---

### 1 Expansion of the denominator

\[
\rho_\varepsilon \;=\; e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho
  \;=\; \rho + \varepsilon\Delta\rho + \tfrac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2}\Delta^{2}\rho + O(\varepsilon^{3}),
\qquad
\rho>0\;\text{(on the region of interest).}
\]

Hence

\[
\frac{1}{\rho_\varepsilon}
  \;=\; \frac{1}{\rho}\bigl(1-\varepsilon\tfrac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}\bigr)
       + O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

---

### 2 Effect on the correction term  

With the leading numerator
\[
N \;=\; 2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho
        \;\sim\; e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)},
\]
the difference produced by the swap is

\[
\varepsilon N\!\left(\frac{1}{\rho_\varepsilon}-\frac{1}{\rho}\right)
  \;=\;
\varepsilon N
\Bigl(-\varepsilon\tfrac{\Delta\rho}{\rho^{2}}\Bigr)
  + O(\varepsilon^{3})
  \;=\; O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

which is beyond the accuracy of a first-order truncation.

---

### 3 Resulting first-order formula

\[
\boxed{
\frac{\mathrm D}{\mathrm Dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon
  = -\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f
    \;+\;
    2\,\varepsilon\,
    \frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}
    \;+\;
    O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr)
    \;+\;
    O(\varepsilon^{2})
}.
\]

* The \(O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr)\) term collects the slower pieces of the commutator such as \((\Delta f)\!\cdot\nabla\rho\) and the divergence-dependent terms.
* The replacement is legitimate as long as \(\rho\) stays bounded away from zero (so the series inversion is uniform). If \(\rho\) vanishes on parts of the domain, the swap is still valid point-wise wherever \(\rho>0\), but uniform error bounds require a more careful partition of the space.

parts:
Let  

\[
\Gamma(t)\;:=\;-2\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t), \qquad 
\Lambda(t)=\int_{0}^{t}(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)\bigl(x(\tau)\bigr)\,d\tau,
\quad 
\lambda_{\min}<0 .
\]

---

## 1 Fix the time–dependent smoothing scale  

Choose

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{-\Gamma(t)}
          =\varepsilon_{*}\,\exp\!\bigl(2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)\bigr)
\;}
\]

with a constant \(0<\varepsilon_{*}\ll1\) so that \(\varepsilon(t)\) always stays in the perturbative regime.

---

## 2 Material derivative with the tuned \(\varepsilon(t)\)

From the first–order result (already verified)

\[
\frac{D}{Dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
           =-S
             +2\,\varepsilon(t)\,
              \frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}
             +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr)
             +O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

use \((\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho/\rho
      =Q_{0}\,e^{\Gamma(t)}\) ( \(Q_{0}=O(1)\) ) to obtain

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{D}{Dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
          =-S+2\varepsilon_{*}
           +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
           +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}^{2}e^{-2\Gamma(t)}\bigr)}.
\]

Because \(\lambda_{\min}<0\), the \(O\!\bigl(e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)\) remainder decays exponentially; the leading part is \(O(1)\).

---

## 3 Total derivative (explicit \(\varepsilon(t)\) dependence)

The total time derivative along the trajectory is

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
      =\frac{D}{Dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
       +\dot{\varepsilon}\,\partial_{\varepsilon}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}.
\]

* \(\displaystyle \dot{\varepsilon}=-(\Gamma')\,\varepsilon
                   =(2\lambda_{\min}+S)\,\varepsilon\).
* \(\displaystyle \partial_{\varepsilon}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
            =\frac{\Delta\rho_{\varepsilon}}{\rho_{\varepsilon}}
            =B_{0}\,e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}
            +O(\varepsilon)\) with \(B_{0}=O(1)\).

Hence

\[
\dot{\varepsilon}\,\partial_{\varepsilon}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
     =(2\lambda_{\min}+S)\,
       \varepsilon_{*}\,e^{-\Gamma(t)}\,
       B_{0}\,e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}
     =O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr),
\]

the same exponentially–decaying order as the remainder above.

---

## 4 Final \(O(1)\) total derivative

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
   =-S+2\varepsilon_{*}
     +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
     +O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}^{2}e^{-2\Gamma(t)}\bigr)}.
\]

Thus, by letting \(\varepsilon(t)\) cancel the fastest exponential growth, both the material and the full time derivatives are uniformly \(O(1)\) for large \(t\); the extra terms decay like \(e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\).

parts:
### Clarifying the notation

* **\(s\)** is the *score* of the (smoothed) density:
  \[
  s(x,t,\varepsilon)\;:=\;\nabla\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,t),
  \qquad
  \rho_\varepsilon \;=\;e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho .
  \]
  In what follows I **do not** rewrite anything with \(s\); all terms are left in
  Jacobian-of-\(f\) and derivatives-of-\(\rho\) form, exactly as you asked.

---

### 1 Material derivative of \(\log\rho_\varepsilon\) (first‐order in \(\varepsilon\))

Denote
\[
S:=\nabla\!\cdot\!f,
\qquad
(\nabla f)_{ij}:=\partial_i f_j .
\]

Using \([e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]=
        \varepsilon\,[\Delta,f\!\cdot\nabla]-\varepsilon\,( \Delta S+2\nabla S\!\cdot\nabla)+O(\varepsilon^2)\)
and \(\mathcal L_f\rho=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\rho)\), one finds
\[
\boxed{
\frac{D}{Dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon
  = -\,S
    \;+\;
    \varepsilon\;
    \frac{
        (\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho
      + 2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho
      - (\Delta S)\,\rho
      - 2\,\nabla S\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho
    }{\rho_\varepsilon}
    \;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}).
}
\tag{A}
\]

The **fastest** scaling piece inside the numerator is the Hessian contraction  
\(2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho\;\sim\;e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\).

---

### 2 Choosing a time-dependent smoothing scale  
Let
\[
\Gamma(t):=-2\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t),
\qquad
\Lambda(t)=\int_0^{t}S(\tau)\,d\tau,
\qquad
\varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{-\Gamma(t)}
            =\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)},
\]
with a small constant \(\varepsilon_{*}\).

---

### 3 Total derivative (explicit \(\varepsilon(t)\) dependence)

Because \(\log\rho_\varepsilon\) now depends on \(t\) **both**
through the flow and through \(\varepsilon(t)\),
\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon
  =\frac{D}{Dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon
   +\dot\varepsilon\,\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon,
\]
where \(\dot\varepsilon=(2\lambda_{\min}+S)\,\varepsilon\) and
\(\partial_\varepsilon\log\rho_\varepsilon=\dfrac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}\).

Insert these into (A), *without* performing any substitutions:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon
  &=
    -\,S
    \;+\;
    \varepsilon\;
    \frac{
        (\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho
        + 2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho
        - (\Delta S)\,\rho
        - 2\,\nabla S\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho
    }{\rho_\varepsilon} \\[6pt]
  &\quad
    +\;
    (2\lambda_{\min}+S)\,
    \varepsilon\,
    \frac{\Delta\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
    \;+\;
    O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\end{aligned}}
\tag{B}
\]

---

### 4 Scaling after the cancellation

With the chosen \(\varepsilon(t)\) the dominant Hessian term in (B) becomes

\[
2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
\frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho_\varepsilon},
\]

which is \(O(1)\) in time; every other contribution is either

* \(O(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\lambda_{\min}t})\) (decays because \(\lambda_{\min}<0\)), or  
* \(O(\varepsilon_{*}^{2}e^{-2\Gamma(t)})\) (second order in \(\varepsilon\)).

Hence the total derivative \(\dfrac{d}{dt}\log\rho_\varepsilon\) stays uniformly
\(O(1)\) for large \(t\) once \(\varepsilon(t)\) is tied to the exponential
stretching / contraction of the flow.

Below is the **full first–order total-time derivative** of the smoothed density, written only with explicit differential operators acting on \(f\) and \(\rho\) (no new shorthand such as \(S\)).  Everything is evaluated along the Lagrangian trajectory \(x(t)\) that solves \(\dot x=f(x)\).

---

### Time-dependent smoothing scale  
Choose the Gaussian-smoothing variance so that it cancels the fastest exponential growth:

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_{*}\,
\exp\!\Bigl(2\lambda_{\min}\,t+\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f\!\bigl(x(\tau)\bigr)\,d\tau\Bigr)
\;},\qquad 0<\varepsilon_{*}\ll1,\;\lambda_{\min}<0 .
\]

---

### Total derivative of \(\log\bigl(e^{\varepsilon(t)\Delta}\rho\bigr)\)

Let \(\rho_{\varepsilon}(t,x):=e^{\varepsilon(t)\Delta}\rho(t,x)\).  
Then, keeping **all first-order terms in \(\varepsilon(t)\)**

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
&= -\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f\\[4pt]
&\quad
-\varepsilon(t)\Biggl[
\frac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho}{\rho}
+
2\,\frac{\bigl(\nabla f\bigr)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}
+
\bigl(\Delta\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)
+
2\,\frac{\nabla\!\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho}{\rho}
\Biggr] \\[10pt]
&\quad
+\bigl(2\lambda_{\min}+\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)\,
\varepsilon(t)\,\frac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}
\;+\;
O\!\bigl(\varepsilon(t)^{2}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\;}
\]

---

### Consequences of the chosen \(\varepsilon(t)\)

The Hessian-contraction piece  
\[
-\,2\,\varepsilon(t)\,\frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}
\]
is the term whose bare magnitude would grow like
\(\exp\!\bigl(-2\lambda_{\min}t-\!\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)\).
Multiplying by the designed \(\varepsilon(t)\) leaves a **time-independent amplitude \(-2\varepsilon_{*}\)**.  
All other first-order contributions either involve only first derivatives of \(\rho\) (which grow at most like \(\exp(-\lambda_{\min}t)\)) or one extra factor of \(\Delta\rho\); each therefore acquires an overall factor that decays like \(e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\).  The \(O\!\bigl(\varepsilon(t)^{2}\bigr)\) remainder is smaller still.

Hence, with this smoothing schedule the entire derivative remains \(O(1)\) for large \(t\):

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\log\rho_{\varepsilon}
= -\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f
-2\varepsilon_{*}
+O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
+O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}^{2}\bigr).
\]

*(The minus sign in front of the Hessian-contraction term corrects the sign that was implicit in the earlier shorthand.)*

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_{*}\,
\exp\Bigl(2\lambda_{\min}\,t+\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f\!\bigl(x(\tau)\bigr)\,d\tau\Bigr)
\;}\qquad(0<\varepsilon_{*}\ll1,\;\lambda_{\min}<0),
\]

is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\frac{d}{dt}\log\!\bigl(e^{\varepsilon(t)\Delta}\rho\bigr)
&= -\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f \\[4pt]
&\;-\;2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
      e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\;
      \frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho} \\[6pt]
&\;-\;\varepsilon_{*}\,
      e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\,
      \Biggl[
        \frac{(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho}{\rho}
        +\bigl(\Delta\,\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)
        +2\;\frac{\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho}{\rho}
        -\bigl(2\lambda_{\min}+\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigr)
         \frac{\Delta\rho}{\rho}
      \Biggr] \\[10pt]
&\;+\;O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}^{2}\,
              e^{\,4\lambda_{\min}t+2\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\bigr).
\end{aligned}}
\]

---

### The “amplitude” of the fastest term  

The piece that used to be written heuristically as a constant \(-2\varepsilon_{*}\) is in fact

\[
\boxed{\;
A(t)\;=\;-\,2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
          e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\;
          \frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}}\;.
\]

Because  
\[
\frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}
        =O\!\bigl(e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\bigr)
\]
along every trajectory, the product \(A(t)\) is **uniformly bounded** (and typically settles to a finite limit that depends on the initial condition), but it is not literally time-independent.

All remaining first-order terms carry the same exponential prefactor  
\(e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\)  
multiplied by quantities that grow at most like  
\(e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot\!f}\);  
hence they decay as \(e^{\lambda_{\min}t}\) and are down by one Lyapunov factor relative to \(A(t)\).  

The \(O(\varepsilon_{*}^{2})\) remainder is yet smaller and can be ignored at first order.

parts:
### Notation fixed once and for all  
* \(x(t)\) satisfies \(\dot x = f(x)\).  
* \(\rho(t,x)\) solves the Liouville equation  
  \(\partial_t\rho + \nabla\!\cdot(f\rho)=0\) with smooth, compactly-supported data.  
* \(s:=\nabla\log\rho\) (the score).  
* The smallest finite–time Lyapunov exponent is negative: \(\lambda_{\min}<0\).  
* \(\Lambda(t):=\displaystyle\int_{0}^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\bigl(x(\tau)\bigr)\,d\tau\).  
* The time–dependent smoothing variance is  
  \[
  \varepsilon(t)=\varepsilon_{*}\exp\!\Bigl(2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)\Bigr),
  \qquad 0<\varepsilon_{*}\ll1 .
  \]

---

## 1 The quantity whose mean we want

\[
\boxed{A(t)\;=\;-\,2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
       e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}\;
       \frac{(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho}{\rho}}
       \qquad\bigl(\text{evaluated at }x(t)\bigr).
\]

Using \(\nabla^{2}\rho/\rho=\nabla s+s\,s^{\!\top}\) this is

\[
A(t)= -\,2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}
      \Bigl[\;(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla s
              + s^{\!\top}\!(\nabla f)\,s\Bigr].
\tag{1}
\]

---

## 2 A(t) is (almost) a total time derivative  

Define one auxiliary quantity—**nothing else will be introduced**:

\[
B(t)\;:=\;
-\,2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}\;
s^{\!\top}(\nabla f).
\tag{2}
\]

Compute its derivative along the trajectory.  

*First part:*  
\[
\frac{d}{dt}e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}
     =(2\lambda_{\min}+\nabla\!\cdot f)\,
       e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)} .
\]

*Second part:*  along the flow the score obeys the well-known identity  
\[
\frac{D}{Dt}s\;=\;-\,\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\;-\;(\nabla f)^{\!\top} s .
\tag{3}
\]

*Putting things together:* straight calculation gives

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{dB}{dt}
   = A(t)\;-\;
     2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
     e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}
     \Bigl[(2\lambda_{\min}+\nabla\!\cdot f)\,s^{\!\top}(\nabla f)
           + s^{\!\top}(\nabla f)^{\!\top}s\Bigr].
     }
\tag{4}
\]

The bracket on the right is \(O\!\bigl(e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr)\):  

* \(s=O\!\bigl(e^{-\lambda_{\min}t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr)\) from the linearisation of (3);  
* the matrices \(\nabla f\) are \(O(1)\).

Therefore

\[
R(t):=
2\,\varepsilon_{*}\,
e^{\,2\lambda_{\min}t+\Lambda(t)}
\Bigl[(2\lambda_{\min}+\nabla\!\cdot f)\,s^{\!\top}(\nabla f)
      + s^{\!\top}(\nabla f)^{\!\top}s\Bigr]
=O\!\bigl(\varepsilon_{*}\,e^{\,\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr).
\tag{5}
\]

Because \(\lambda_{\min}<0\), \(R(t)\) decays exponentially.

Equation (4) is the promised “total–derivative” representation:

\[
A(t)=\frac{dB}{dt}+R(t)\quad\text{with }R(t)\xrightarrow[t\to\infty]{}0.
\tag{6}
\]

---

## 3 Time average of \(A(t)\)

Take the time average over \([0,T]\):

\[
\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}A(t)\,dt
     \;=\;\frac{B(T)-B(0)}{T}
          \;+\;\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}R(t)\,dt.
\tag{7}
\]

* **Bound on \(B\).**  
  From (2) and the decay of \(s\),  
  \( |B(t)|\le C\,\varepsilon_{*}\) for all \(t\), hence  
  \(\displaystyle\frac{|B(T)-B(0)|}{T}\le\frac{2C\varepsilon_{*}}{T}\xrightarrow[T\to\infty]{}0\).

* **Bound on the integral of \(R(t)\).**  
  Using (5),  
  \(\displaystyle\Bigl|\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}R(t)\,dt\Bigr|
      \le\frac{C'\varepsilon_{*}}{T}
           \int_{0}^{T}e^{\,\lambda_{\min}t}\,dt
      =\frac{C'\varepsilon_{*}}{T( -\lambda_{\min})}
           \bigl(1-e^{\,\lambda_{\min}T}\bigr)
      \xrightarrow[T\to\infty]{}0\).

---

## 4 Conclusion  

\[
\boxed{\;
\lim_{T\to\infty}\frac1T\int_{0}^{T}A(t)\,dt\;=\;0.
\;}
\]

Hence **the long-time average of the amplitude \(A(t)\) vanishes.**  
No additional substitutions, abbreviations, or hidden constants were used beyond the single auxiliary \(B(t)\), whose boundedness and the exponential decay in \(R(t)\) jointly force the average of \(A(t)\) to zero.

No—since \( \dfrac{1}{1+x}=1-x+x^{2}-x^{3}+\cdots\), we have  
\[
\left|1-\frac{1}{1+x}\right|=\bigl|x-x^{2}+x^{3}-\cdots\bigr|=\frac{|x|}{|1+x|}=O(x)\quad(x\to0),
\]
whereas  
\[
\left|\bigl(1-x\bigr)-\frac{1}{1+x}\right|=\left|x^{2}-x^{3}+\cdots\right|=O\!\left(x^{2}\right).
\]

The user wants the precise Θ scaling of \( e^{\varepsilon \Delta} e^{t \mathcal{L}_f} \rho_0(x) \), considering both \( \varepsilon \) and \( t \). The scaling will involve the Liouville flow transformation and Gaussian smoothing. The amplitude of the density could grow or decay depending on the divergence in the flow, while the smoothing scales with \( \sqrt{\varepsilon} \). It seems they expect an expression of the form \( Θ(\exp(-∫_0^t ∇·f) + \text{smoothing}) \), but the question might be ambiguous – clarification might be helpful.

To calculate the scaling of \( e^{\varepsilon \Delta} e^{t \mathcal{L}_f} \rho_0(x) \), we consider the interplay between Liouville flow and smoothing. For small \( \varepsilon \), smoothing dominates, and the amplitude scales roughly as \( \varepsilon^{-n/2} \). In contrast, for large \( \varepsilon \), the amplitude depends on the divergence of the flow. The overall scaling seems to be dominated by \( e^{t \Lambda} \), where \( \Lambda \) is the Lyapunov exponent. Hence, the scaling is \( \Theta(e^{-t \Sigma \lambda_i^-}) \). This considers both flow and smoothing contributions.

For small \( \varepsilon \), the amplitude scales as \( \Theta(e^{- \sum \lambda_i t}) \), while for large \( \varepsilon \), it's dominated by smoothing, scaling as \( \Theta(\varepsilon^{-n/2} e^{- \sum \lambda_i t}) \). The expression can be approximated as \( \Theta(1) + \Theta(\varepsilon e^{-2 \lambda_{\min} t}) \) for large \( \varepsilon \), where the second term accounts for smoothing corrections. This considers both flow dynamics and smoothing at different scales.

parts:
Write the Liouville‐evolved density as  

\[
\rho_t(x)\;=\;e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)
           \;=\;\rho_0\!\bigl(\Phi_{-t}(x)\bigr)\;
               \exp\!\Bigl[-\!\int_{0}^{t}\!\nabla\!\cdot\!f\bigl(\Phi_{s-t}(x)\bigr)\,ds\Bigr],
\]

so \(\rho_t\) carries an overall factor  
\(\Theta\!\bigl(e^{-\!\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\,ds}\bigr)\), common to every term below and therefore omitted from the scaling symbols.

---

### Lyapunov control of derivatives  
For a smooth initial density and flow with smallest (most negative) Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_{\min}<0\),

\[
\|\nabla^k\rho_t\|_\infty
\;=\;\Theta\!\bigl(e^{-k\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr),
\qquad k=0,1,2,\dots
\]

(The norm can be any pointwise, Hölder, or \(L^\infty\) norm; the Θ–statement is unchanged.)

---

### Heat–semigroup expansion  
Because \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}= \sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\Delta^{m}\),

\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0
 \;=\;\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\,\Delta^{m}\rho_t.
\]

Using the derivative scaling above and \(\Delta^{m}\rho_t=\nabla^{2m}\rho_t\),

\[
\Delta^{m}\rho_t
\;=\;\Theta\!\bigl(e^{-2m\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr),
\]

so each term in the series satisfies  

\[
\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\Delta^{m}\rho_t
\;=\;\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{m}e^{-2m\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr).
\]

---

### Collecting the Θ contributions  

\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0
=\Theta\!\Bigl(
1\;+\;\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}
\;+\;\varepsilon^{2}e^{-4\lambda_{\min}t}
\;+\;\dots\Bigr).
\]

---

### Regimes and crossover  

* **If** \(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\ll 1\)\;(equivalently \(t< t^{*}\)),  
  the series is dominated by its zeroth term:

  \[
  e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0
  \;=\;\Theta(1).
  \]

* **If** \(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\gtrsim 1\)\;( \(t\ge t^{*}\)),  
  the \(m=1\) term grows past the zeroth term and controls the scaling:

  \[
  e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0
  \;=\;\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr).
  \]

Here  

\[
t^{*}\;=\;\frac{1}{2|\lambda_{\min}|}\,\log\!\frac{1}{\varepsilon}
\]

is the sharp crossover time beyond which smoothing (order-\(\varepsilon\)) and the exponential growth of second derivatives (\(e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\)) balance.

---

### Compact statement  

\[
\boxed{\;
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)
\;=\;\Theta\!\bigl(1+\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
\;
}
\quad(\varepsilon\ll1,\;t\ge0).
\]

Multiplying back the common geometric factor \(e^{-\!\int_0^{t}\nabla\!\cdot f\,ds}\) gives the complete pointwise Θ–scaling of the smoothed density.

parts:
Let  

\[
\rho_t(x)\;=\;e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x),\qquad 
\mathcal L_f\rho =-\,\nabla\!\cdot\!(f\rho).
\]

---

### 1.  Closed-form commutator  

Acting on an arbitrary smooth field \(\phi\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\phi
&=\Delta\bigl(-\nabla\!\cdot(f\phi)\bigr)
      +\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\,\Delta\phi\bigr) \\[4pt]
&=-\,\phi\,\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)
      -2\,\nabla\phi\!\cdot\!\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)
      -2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\phi
      -(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\phi .
\end{aligned}
\]

(Here “\(:\)” is the Frobenius double dot between matrices, so  
\((\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\phi= \sum_{i,j}\partial_i f_j\,\partial_{ij}\phi\).)

---

### 2.  Lyapunov control of \(\rho_t\) derivatives  

For the smallest (most negative) Lyapunov exponent \(\lambda_{\min}<0\)

\[
\|\nabla^{k}\rho_t\|_\infty
=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{-k\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr),
\qquad k=0,1,2,\dots
\]

---

### 3.  Θ-scaling of every term  

Insert \(\phi=\rho_t\) into the commutator and multiply by \(\varepsilon\):

| piece | analytic form | Θ-size |
|-------|---------------|--------|
| A | \(-\varepsilon\,\rho_t\,\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon)\) |
| B | \(-2\varepsilon\,\nabla\rho_t\!\cdot\!\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)\) |
| C | \(-2\varepsilon\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\rho_t\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)\) |
| D | \(-\varepsilon\,(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t\) | \(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)\) |

Because \(-\lambda_{\min}>0\), the Hessian–coupling term **C** grows fastest with \(t\) and dominates for large times.

---

### 4.  Compact result  

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon\,[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\,e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)
=\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
\quad\text{(leading)}\;},
\]

with sub-leading contributions  
\(\Theta(\varepsilon e^{-\lambda_{\min}t})\) and \(\Theta(\varepsilon)\) that are slower in the prescribed \(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\) sense.

Essentially, we expand \(e^{\varepsilon \Delta}\) as \(I + \varepsilon \Delta + \frac{\varepsilon^2}{2}\Delta^2 + \ldots\). Plugging this into the commutator:

\[
[e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f] = [I + \varepsilon \Delta + \frac{\varepsilon^2}{2} \Delta^2 + \ldots , \mathcal{L}_f]
\]

This gives the first-order expansion:

\[
\varepsilon[\Delta, \mathcal{L}_f] + \frac{\varepsilon^2}{2}[\Delta^2, \mathcal{L}_f] + \ldots
\]

For their request, I’ll ignore terms with \(\varepsilon^2\) and higher.

The user is asking for the full expansion of the commutator \([e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f]\), ignoring \(\varepsilon^2\) or higher. So, based on the earlier work, the answer at first order is:

\[
[e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f]\phi = \varepsilon \left( -\phi \Delta (\nabla \cdot f) - 2 \nabla \phi \cdot \nabla (\nabla \cdot f) - (\Delta f) \cdot \nabla \phi - 2 (\nabla f)^{\top} : \nabla^2 \phi \right) + O(\varepsilon^2)
\]

And we can also express this in the operator form:

parts:
Using the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff expansion for the exponential,  

\[
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]
   \;=\;\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\,
        \operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_f),
   \qquad\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_f)=
        [\underbrace{\Delta,[\Delta,\dots[\Delta}_{m\text{ times}},\mathcal L_f]\dots]] .
\]

Ignoring every term that carries \(\varepsilon^{2}\) or higher powers leaves only the \(m=1\) contribution:  

\[
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]
   \;=\;\varepsilon\,[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

---

### Explicit first-order commutator  

For any smooth field \(\phi\) and writing \(g=\nabla\!\cdot f\),

\[
\boxed{\;
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\phi
   =-\,\phi\,\Delta g
     -2\,\nabla\phi\!\cdot\!\nabla g
     -(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\phi
     -2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\phi
\;}
\]

(with “\(:\)” the double-dot product \((\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\phi=\sum_{i,j}\partial_i f_j\,\partial_{ij}\phi\)).

---

### Full first-order expansion of the exponential commutator  

Therefore, up to and including all \(\Theta(\varepsilon)\) contributions,

\[
\boxed{\;
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]\phi
   =-\varepsilon
     \Bigl[
       \phi\,\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)
       +2\,\nabla\phi\!\cdot\!\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)
       +(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\phi
       +2\,(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla^{2}\phi
     \Bigr]
   \;+\;O(\varepsilon^{2})
\;}
\]

All terms shown are exactly of first order in \(\varepsilon\); every term containing \(\varepsilon^{2}\) or higher is omitted.

The convolution prefactor integrates to 1, and the scaling depends on the region in question. parts:
Because the heat operator is **a *convolution* with a Gaussian that integrates to 1**, the apparent \((4\pi\varepsilon)^{-n/2}\) prefactor of the kernel never survives once the integral is carried out on a *smooth* integrand.

---

### 1 Heat semigroup as convolution  

\[
(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}f)(x)
=\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}
\underbrace{(4\pi\varepsilon)^{-n/2}\,
           e^{-\lvert x-y\rvert^{2}/(4\varepsilon)}}_{g_\varepsilon(x-y)}
\,f(y)\,dy .
\]

The kernel’s \(L^\infty\)-size is \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{-n/2})\), but its support that appreciably contributes has radius \(\sim\!\sqrt{\varepsilon}\) and hence volume \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{n/2})\).  Their product cancels in the integral whenever \(f\) is bounded on that neighbourhood.

---

### 2 Local expansion for a *smooth* \(f\)  

Write \(y=x+\sqrt{\varepsilon}\,z\).  Taylor–expand \(f\):

\[
f(y)=f(x)
      +\sqrt{\varepsilon}\,z\!\cdot\!\nabla f(x)
      +\tfrac{\varepsilon}{2}\,z_i z_j \partial_{ij}f(x)
      +O(\varepsilon^{3/2}).
\]

Because \(g_\varepsilon\) becomes the standard Gaussian in \(z\),

\[
\int z_i\,e^{-\lvert z\rvert^{2}/4}\,dz=0,\qquad
\int z_i z_j\,e^{-\lvert z\rvert^{2}/4}\,dz=2\delta_{ij}.
\]

Therefore

\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}f(x)
=f(x)+\varepsilon\Delta f(x)+O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

**no negative power of \(\varepsilon\)** appears.  
This is the statement we used when we wrote  
\(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0
   =\Theta\bigl(1+\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)\).

---

### 3 When does \(\varepsilon^{-n/2}\) *really* show up?  

* **Singular data.**  
  If \(f\) itself carries an \(\varepsilon\)-scale singularity—e.g. \(f=\delta_0\)—then  

  \[
  e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\delta_0=g_\varepsilon
  =\Theta(\varepsilon^{-n/2})\quad\text{pointwise}.
  \]

  Your prefactor appears exactly in this *non-smooth* case.

* **Smooth data.**  
  For any \(f\in C^k(\mathbb R^n)\) with \(k\ge2\) (our assumption for \(\rho_t\)), the convolution is a local weighted average; the kernel’s height and its \(\sqrt{\varepsilon}\)-width cancel, leaving the expansion above.

---

### 4 Application to the dynamical density  

We assumed from the outset

\[
\rho_t(x)=e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x),\qquad 
\rho_0\in C^{\infty},\; t\ge0,
\]

so every \(\rho_t\) is \(C^\infty\) and bounded on compact sets.  
Hence the dominant term of \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\) is \(\rho_t\) itself (Θ-size 1), followed by \(\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t\) (Θ-size \(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\)).  No \(\varepsilon^{-n/2}\) survives.

---

### 5 Summary in Θ-notation  

\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)
=\Theta\!\Bigl(1+\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\Bigr)
\quad\text{provided } \rho_0\in C^{2}.
\]

If you drop the smooth-data assumption and start with singular measures (Dirac masses, fractal measures, etc.), the \(\varepsilon^{-n/2}\) factor *does* emerge; but that is a fundamentally different regime from the one analysed in the previous answer.

\partial_t s &= \partial_t \nabla \log \rho_\varepsilon(x,t) \\
&= \partial_t \nabla \log e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x) \\
&= \nabla \frac{e^{\varepsilon \Delta} \mathcal{L}_f e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}{e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)} \\
&= \nabla \left(\frac{\mathcal{L}_f e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}{e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)} + \frac{[e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f] e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}{e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}\right) \\

Below is a compact but complete continuation of the computation, with every term kept that is at least  
\(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-2\lambda t}\bigr)\).  Quantities that decay strictly faster, i.e.  
\(\mathcal{O}\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-3\lambda t}\bigr)\), and all higher–order powers of \(\varepsilon\) are dropped.

---

### 1.  Notation and useful identities  

| symbol | meaning | scaling assumption |
|--------|---------|--------------------|
| \(\rho_\varepsilon=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0\) | smoothed density | — |
| \(s=\nabla\log\rho_\varepsilon\) | score field | \(\|s\|=\Theta(e^{-\lambda t})\) |
| \(H=\nabla s=\nabla^2\!\log\rho_\varepsilon\) | Hessian of log‐density | \(\|H\|=\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})\) |
| \(f:\mathbb R^d\to\mathbb R^d\) | drift field | smooth, time‑independent |
| \(J=\nabla f\) | Jacobian of \(f\) | constant in time |
| \(b=\nabla\!\cdot\!f\) | divergence of \(f\) | constant in time |

For any smooth scalar \(g\),
\[
\begin{aligned}
\partial_i\partial_j g &= H_{ij}g + s_i s_j g,\\
\frac{\partial_j g}{g} &= s_j .
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2.  Zero‑order (\(\varepsilon^0\)) contribution  

Using the Liouville (deterministic Fokker–Planck) generator  
\(\mathcal L_f g=-\nabla\!\cdot\!(fg)=-f\!\cdot\!\nabla g -(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)g\),

\[
\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
      =-(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)-f\!\cdot\!s ,
\]
hence
\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t s^{(0)}=-\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)\;-\;J^{\!\top}s\;-\;(f\!\cdot\!\nabla)s
\;} .
\]
The three terms scale respectively like  
\(\Theta(1),\;\Theta(e^{-\lambda t}),\;\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})\); all exceed the retention threshold.

---

### 3.  First‑order commutator  

Write
\[
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]
    =\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]+{\cal O}(\varepsilon^2),
\qquad
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho
      =-\Delta(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho)+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\Delta\rho
        -\Delta\!\bigl((\nabla\!\cdot\!f)\rho\bigr)
        +(\nabla\!\cdot\!f)\Delta\rho .
\]

After expanding with product rules and rearranging,

\[
\frac{[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho}{\rho}
 =-\underbrace{\Delta f_j\,s_j}_{\Theta(e^{-\lambda t})}
   -2\,\underbrace{\partial_i f_j\,
       (\,H_{ij}+s_i s_j)}_{\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})}
   -\underbrace{\Delta b}_{\Theta(1)}
   -2\,\underbrace{\partial_i b\,s_i}_{\Theta(e^{-\lambda t})}
   +{\cal O}(e^{-3\lambda t}).
\]

---

### 4.  Gradient of the commutator ratio  

Only derivatives that do **not** push the scaling below
\(\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})\) are retained.  That means

* \(\nabla(\Delta f_j\,s_j)
      =(\nabla\Delta f_j)s_j+\Delta f_j\,H_{jk}e_k
      +{\cal O}(e^{-3\lambda t})\);
* \(\nabla(\partial_i b\,s_i)
      =\partial_i b\,H_{ik}e_k+{\cal O}(e^{-3\lambda t})\);
* gradients acting on \(H_{ij}\) or on \(s_i s_j\) give
  \(\mathcal O(e^{-3\lambda t})\) and are therefore discarded.

Collecting the surviving pieces gives

\[
\boxed{\;
\varepsilon\,\partial_t s^{(1)}
 =-\varepsilon\bigl[(\nabla\Delta f)\,s
                     +\Delta f\!\cdot\!H
                     +\nabla\Delta b
                     +2\,(\nabla b)\!\cdot\!H
               \bigr]
 +\mathcal O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-3\lambda t}\bigr)
\;} .
\]

---

### 5.  Full evolution to the requested accuracy  

Combining the zero‑ and first‑order parts,

\[
\boxed{
\partial_t s
 =-\nabla b
  -J^{\!\top}s
  -(f\!\cdot\!\nabla)s
  \;+\;
  \varepsilon\Bigl[
        -(\nabla\Delta f)\,s
        -\Delta f\!\cdot\!H
        -\nabla\Delta b
        -2\,(\nabla b)\!\cdot\!H
     \Bigr]
  +\mathcal O\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,e^{-3\lambda t}\bigr)
}
\]

with

* \(s=\nabla\log\rho_\varepsilon=\Theta(e^{-\lambda t})\),
* \(H=\nabla s=\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})\),
* \(b=\nabla\!\cdot\!f,\;J=\nabla f\).

Every explicit term displayed decays no faster than
\(\Theta(e^{-2\lambda t})\) (or \(\Theta(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda t})\) in the
\(\varepsilon\)-sector) and thus meets the cutoff criterion.

Assume \rho_0(x) is a smooth density. L_f is the Liouville operator for a drift f. For the following expression:

\frac{[e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f] e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}{e^{\varepsilon \Delta}e^{t \mathcal{L}_f}\rho_0(x)}

Expand and calculate all relevant terms. Rules for relevant terms:

1. Ignore terms slower than \Theta(\varepsilon e^{-2 \lambda_\text{min} t}) in time
2. Ignore terms of order O(\varepsilon^2)
3. Don't ignore \Theta(1)

where \lambda_min is the smallest lyapunov exponent (negative). Make sure to account for all of them at the end! To help you along, you may assume:

Where \lambda = - \lambda_\text{min}(x_0,t). If you need to use any other scaling laws you must be explicit in deriving them

**Step 1 – First–order (in ε) expansion of the operators**

\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}=I+\varepsilon\Delta+O(\varepsilon^{2}),\qquad
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_{f}]
   =\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]+O(\varepsilon^{2}).
\]

Let  
\[
\rho_t(x)\equiv e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x).
\]

Then  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]\,\rho_t}
      {e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t}}
  =\frac{\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t+O(\varepsilon^{2})}
         {\rho_t+\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t+O(\varepsilon^{2})}.
}
\]

---

**Step 2 – Work out the commutator \([\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\)**  

For a smooth test function \(\varphi\),

\[
\mathcal L_f\varphi=-\nabla\!\cdot(f\varphi)
                  =-(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\varphi-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\varphi .
\]

A direct calculation (keep only the terms you will need below) gives  

\[
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\varphi
 =-\,\underbrace{\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)}_{S(x)}\,\varphi
 -2\,\underbrace{\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)}_{T(x)}\!\cdot\!\nabla\varphi
 -\underbrace{(\Delta f)}_{R(x)}\!\cdot\!\nabla\varphi
 -2\,\underbrace{\partial_i f_j}_{A_{ij}(x)}\,\partial_i\partial_j\varphi .
\]

The last term contains **two spatial derivatives of \(\varphi\)**; all others contain 0 or 1.

---

**Step 3 – Apply the user‑supplied growth estimates**

For the advected density \(\rho_t\) we are given  

\[
\|\nabla^{k}\rho_t\|=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr),\qquad
\lambda\equiv-\lambda_{\min}>0 .
\]

Hence  

| term in \([\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t\) | growth rate | comment |
|------------------------------------------|-------------|---------|
| \(-\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_t\) | \(e^{0\cdot\lambda t}=e^{0}\) | slower |
| \(-2\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t\) | \(e^{1\lambda t}\) | slower |
| \(-(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_t\) | \(e^{1\lambda t}\) | slower |
| \(-2\,\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t\) | \(e^{2\lambda t}\) | **fastest** |

The prescription tells us to **ignore anything that grows more slowly than  
\(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)
       =\Theta(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t})\).**  
After multiplying by the explicit prefactor \(\varepsilon\), only the \(k=2\) contribution survives:

\[
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t
   =-2\,\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t
     +\text{(discarded\,terms)} .
\]

---

**Step 4 – Identify the leading piece of the denominator**

\[
\rho_t =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{0}\bigr),\qquad
\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t=\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t}\bigr).
\]

Because \(e^{2\lambda t}\) eventually dominates any fixed constant, the
\(\rho_t\) term is **slower** than \(\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t\) and is dropped
under rule 1.  Thus

\[
\rho_t+\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t
  =\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t
   +\text{(discarded\,terms)} .
\]

---

**Step 5 – Assemble the relevant contribution**

\[
\frac{[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]\rho_t}
     {e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t}
   =\frac{\varepsilon\bigl[-2\,\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t\bigr]}
          {\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t}
   +\text{(discarded of order }O(\varepsilon^{2})\text{ or slower)} .
\]

All factors \(\varepsilon\) cancel, so the requested expression reduces to a **pure \(O(1)\)** object:

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f]\,
        e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)}
      {e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\,e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)}
  =-2\,
    \frac{\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t(x)}
         {\Delta\rho_t(x)}
  +\;O(\varepsilon^{2})\;+\;\text{(terms slower than }
        \Theta(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t})) }.
\]

---

### Remarks and checks

* **No \(O(\varepsilon)\)** piece survives:  
  every term of that order is accompanied by growth \(e^{0\lambda t}\) or
  \(e^{1\lambda t}\) and is therefore “too slow’’ by rule 1.

* The final answer is explicitly **\(O(1)\)** in \(\varepsilon\) and grows no
  faster than \(e^{0\lambda t}\); hence it is retained.

* Higher‐order corrections (\(O(\varepsilon^{2})\)) and all contributions
  proportional to \(e^{0\lambda t}\) or \(e^{\lambda t}\) have been omitted, as mandated.

By rewriting second derivatives using the Hessian of \( \log ρ_t \) and the score, we get the expression \( \partial_i \partial_j ρ_t = ρ_t (H_{ij} + s_i s_j) \), and the denominator as \( Δρ_t = ρ_t (\nabla·s + ||s||^2) \). The final term simplifies to:

\[
Term = -2 (∇f) : (∇^2 \log ρ_t + s ⊗ s) / (∇·s + ||s||^2)
\]

Let  

\[
s(x,t)\;:=\;\nabla\!\log \rho_t(x),\qquad 
H(x,t)\;:=\;\nabla^2\!\log \rho_t(x)\;(=\nabla s^\top).
\]

---

### Rewrite the numerator  
Using the identity  
\[
\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t \;=\;\rho_t\bigl(H_{ij}+s_i s_j\bigr),
\]
we obtain  

\[
\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t
   \;=\;\rho_t\Bigl[\,
        (\nabla f)\!:\!H \;+\; s^\top(\nabla f)\,s
     \Bigr].
\]

---

### Rewrite the denominator  
\[
\Delta\rho_t
    \;=\;\rho_t\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot s+\|s\|^2\bigr).
\]

---

### Insert into the isolated term  
The ratio \(\rho_t/\rho_t\) cancels, so the \(\varepsilon\)-independent contribution you isolated becomes

\[
\boxed{\;
-\,2\,
\frac{(\nabla f)\!:\!H \;+\; s^{\!\top}(\nabla f)\,s}
      {\nabla\!\cdot s+\|s\|^2}
\;}
\]

or, equivalently, in compact tensor notation,

\[
-\,2\,
\frac{\displaystyle 
      \operatorname{tr}\!\Bigl[(\nabla f)^\top\bigl(H+s\!\otimes\!s\bigr)\Bigr]}
     {\nabla\!\cdot s+\|s\|^2}.
\]

Thus the entire leading-order contribution is expressed solely in terms of the **score** \(s=\nabla\log\rho_t\) and its Hessian \(H=\nabla s^\top\).

parts:
Let  

\[
Q(x,t)\;:=\;-2\,\frac{\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t}{\Delta\rho_t},
\qquad
\rho_t:=e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0 .
\]

---

### 1.  Pre-compute the pieces and their scalings  

Using  
\[
\|\nabla^{k}\rho_t\|=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t-\Lambda(t)}\bigr),
\qquad \lambda=-\lambda_{\min}>0,
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
B &:=\Delta\rho_t
      =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr),\\[3pt]
\nabla B &=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr),\\[3pt]
A &:=\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t
      =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr), \\[3pt]
\nabla A &=\partial_k(\partial_i f_j\,\partial_i\partial_j\rho_t)
         =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

(Derivatives of \(f\) are \(O(1)\) in time, so they do not affect the exponential factors.)

---

### 2.  Differentiate \(Q\)

\[
\nabla Q
 =-2\,\frac{\nabla A}{B}
   +2\,A\,\frac{\nabla B}{B^{2}}
 =-2\,\frac{\nabla A\,B-A\,\nabla B}{B^{2}} .
\]

---

### 3.  Scale each term  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\nabla A\,B     &:\ \Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr)\cdot
                  \Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr)
                 =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{5\lambda t-2\Lambda}\bigr),\\
A\,\nabla B     &:\ \Theta\!\bigl(e^{2\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr)\cdot
                  \Theta\!\bigl(e^{3\lambda t-\Lambda}\bigr)
                 =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{5\lambda t-2\Lambda}\bigr),\\[4pt]
B^{2}           &:\ \bigl(\Theta(e^{2\lambda t-\Lambda})\bigr)^{2}
                 =\Theta\!\bigl(e^{4\lambda t-2\Lambda}\bigr).
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 4.  Net growth of the gradient  

\[
\boxed{\;
\|\nabla Q(x,t)\|=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{\lambda t}\bigr)
\;}
\]

Hence the spatial gradient of the surviving \(O(1)\) term grows exponentially in time with rate \(\lambda=-\lambda_{\min}\).  All slower contributions (e.g.\ those involving only \(O(e^{2\lambda t})\) factors in the numerator) are sub-dominant and have been discarded per the original relevance rules.

parts:
Let  

\[
\rho_t(x)=e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x),\qquad 
\mathcal L_f\rho=-\nabla\!\cdot\!(f\rho)=-(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho .
\]

---

### 1.  Exact time–derivative

\[
\partial_t\log\bigl(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\bigr)
      =\frac{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\,\partial_t\rho_t}{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t}
      =\frac{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_f\rho_t}{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t}.
\]

---

### 2.  First-order expansion in \(\varepsilon\)

Using \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}=1+\varepsilon\Delta+\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2)\) and  
\(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_f=\mathcal L_f+\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]+\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2)\),

\[
\frac{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_f\rho_t}{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t}
      =\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t+\varepsilon[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t}{\rho_t+\varepsilon\Delta\rho_t}
      =\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t}{\rho_t}
       +\varepsilon\Bigl(\frac{[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t}{\rho_t}
                         -\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t\,\Delta\rho_t}{\rho_t^{\;2}}\Bigr)
       +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).\tag{A}
\]

---

### 3.  Leading (\(\Theta(1)\)) term  

\[
\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t}{\rho_t}=-(\nabla\!\cdot f)-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t .
\]

* \(-\nabla\!\cdot f=\Theta(1)\) (retain).
* \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t=\Theta(e^{\lambda t})\) by the user’s scaling  
  \(\|\nabla\rho_t\|=\Theta(e^{\lambda t})\).  
  Since \(e^{\lambda t}\ll\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t}\) for large \(t\) (Rule 1) we **discard** this part.

Thus  

\[
\boxed{\text{O(1) part}\;=\;-\nabla\!\cdot f.}
\]

---

### 4.  The commutator term  \([\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\)

For a scalar \(\psi\),

\[
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\psi
   =-2\,\partial_i f_j\,\partial_{ij}\psi
     -(\Delta f_j)\,\partial_j\psi
     -2\,\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\psi
     -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\psi .
\]

Hence  

\[
\frac{[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t}{\rho_t}
   =-2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^2\log\rho_t
     -(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t
     -2\,\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t
     -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f).
\]

Scaling:

* \(\nabla^2\log\rho_t=\Theta(e^{2\lambda t})\)  ⇒ whole term \(\Theta(e^{2\lambda t})\).
* Any piece with fewer than two derivatives on \(\rho_t\) is \(\Theta(e^{\lambda t})\) or \(\Theta(1)\).

Keep only the \(\Theta(e^{2\lambda t})\) pieces (Rule 1) **plus** the constant one:

\[
\boxed{\frac{[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho_t}{\rho_t}
      \;\;\rightsquigarrow\;\;
      -2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^2\log\rho_t
      -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f).}
\]

(The mixed \( \nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t \) term is \(\Theta(e^{\lambda t})\) and is dropped.)

---

### 5.  The product term  

Write

\[
\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t}{\rho_t}=-(\nabla\!\cdot f)-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t,\qquad
\frac{\Delta\rho_t}{\rho_t}=\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2 .
\]

Hence

\[
-\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_t\,\Delta\rho_t}{\rho_t^{\;2}}
  =(\nabla\!\cdot f)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr)
   +\bigl(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\bigr)
    \bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr).
\]

* First bracket: \(\Theta(e^{2\lambda t})\)  ⇒ **keep**.
* Second bracket: \(\Theta(e^{3\lambda t})\)  ⇒ grows even faster, **keep**.

---

### 6.  Collecting the surviving pieces

Discarding every contribution ruled out by (1)–(2) and keeping \(\Theta(1)\), we obtain  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\partial_t\log\!\bigl(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0\bigr)
  &= -\,\nabla\!\cdot f \\
  &\quad +\varepsilon\Bigl[
     -2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^2\log\rho_t
     -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f) \\
  &\qquad\qquad
     +(\nabla\!\cdot f)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr) \\
  &\qquad\qquad
     +\bigl(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\bigr)
      \bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr)
     \Bigr]
  +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).
\end{aligned}}
\]

* First line: the sole \(\Theta(1)\) contribution.
* Bracketed block: every term scales **at least** as \(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t}\) (or faster) and is therefore retained.

All terms that are \(O(\varepsilon^2)\) or decay/grow more slowly than  
\(\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{-2\lambda_{\min}t}\bigr)=\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t}\bigr)\) **have been omitted**, respecting Rules 1–2.

### Material derivative along the flow \( \dot x=f(x) \)

For any scalar field \(\Phi(x,t)\),
\[
\frac{D}{Dt}\,\Phi \;=\;\partial_t\Phi+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\Phi .
\]

Putting  
\(\displaystyle\Phi(x,t)=\log\!\bigl(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0(x)\bigr)
     =\log G_t(x)\) with \(G_t=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t\):

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\frac{D}{Dt}\log G_t
      =\partial_t\log G_t
       +f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log G_t }.
\]

---

### Scaling of every algebraic contribution

Assume  

\[
\|\nabla^k\rho_t\|=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t}\bigr),\qquad
\|\nabla^k\log G_t\|=\Theta\!\bigl(e^{k\lambda t}\bigr),\qquad
\lambda:=-\lambda_{\min}>0,
\]
and that \(f\) and its spatial derivatives are \(\Theta(1)\).

| label | term in \(D\log G_t/Dt\) | dominant rate \(=\Theta\!\bigl(\varepsilon^{m}e^{n\lambda t}\bigr)\) |
|-------|-------------------------|-------------------------------------------|
| **(0)** | \(-\,\nabla\!\cdot f\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{0}e^{0\lambda t})\) |
| **(adv)** | \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log G_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{0}e^{1\lambda t})\) |
| **(1)** | \(-2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^{2}\log\rho_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| **(2)** | \(-(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{1\lambda t})\) |
| **(3)** | \(-2\,\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{1\lambda t})\) |
| **(4)** | \(-\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{0\lambda t})\) |
| **(5)** | \((\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\Delta\log\rho_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| **(6)** | \((\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| **(7)** | \((f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\,\Delta\log\rho_t\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{3\lambda t})\) |
| **(8)** | \((f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\,\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\) | \(\Theta(\varepsilon^{1}e^{3\lambda t})\) |

* **Rule-of-thumb relevance**  
  * Terms with rate \(\Theta(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t})\) or faster (rows 1, 5–8) and the \(\Theta(1)\) base term (row 0) dominate for large \(t\).  
  * The pure advection piece (row adv) grows like \(e^{\lambda t}\); it is slower than the \(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t}\) benchmark and can be discarded under the original filtering rule, but is shown here for completeness.  
  * Rows 2–4 are likewise slower and are usually omitted under the same criterion.

Thus, after applying the same relevance rules as before,  

\[
\frac{D}{Dt}\log G_t
   =-\nabla\!\cdot f
    +\varepsilon\Bigl[
       -2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^{2}\log\rho_t
       +(\nabla\!\cdot f)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\bigr)\\
       +\bigl(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\bigr)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\bigr)
     \Bigr]
    +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\]

with every retained term scaling at least as fast as \(\Theta(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t})\) (or as \(\Theta(1)\)) in time.

parts:
---

### Material (Lagrangian) derivative

Let  
\[
S(x,t)\;:=\;\log\!\bigl(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho_t(x)\bigr), 
\qquad\rho_t=e^{t\mathcal L_f}\rho_0 .
\]

The **material derivative** along the flow generated by \(f\) is  
\[
\frac{\mathrm D S}{\mathrm Dt}
      =\partial_t S+f\!\cdot\!\nabla S .
\]

---

#### 1.  First–order expansion of \(S\)

Using \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}=1+\varepsilon\Delta+\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2)\):

\[
S=\log\rho_t
  +\varepsilon\bigl[\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr]
  +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

Hence  
\[
\nabla S
  =\nabla\log\rho_t
   +\varepsilon\nabla\!\bigl[\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr]
   +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

---

#### 2.  Eulerian time–derivative \(\partial_t S\)

From the Liouville equation and the commutator computed earlier:

\[
\partial_t S
  =-\nabla\!\cdot f
   \;-\;f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t
   +\varepsilon\!\left[
        -2(\nabla f):\nabla^2\log\rho_t
        -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\right.
\]
\[
\left.
        +(\nabla\!\cdot f)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr)
        +(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\bigl(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr)
      \right]
   +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

---

#### 3.  Adding the convective piece \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla S\)

\[
f\!\cdot\!\nabla S
  =f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t
   +\varepsilon\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla\!\bigl[\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^2\bigr]
   +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^2).
\]

---

#### 4.  Cancellation of the bare advective term  

The two terms \(\boxed{-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t}\) (from \(\partial_t S\)) and  
\(\boxed{+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t}\) (from \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla S\)) cancel **exactly**.  
Therefore, to first order in \(\varepsilon\),

\[
\boxed{\frac{\mathrm D S}{\mathrm Dt}
  = -\,\nabla\!\cdot f
    +\varepsilon\Bigl[
       -2(\nabla f):\nabla^{2}\log\rho_t
       -\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)
       +(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\left(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\right)}
\]
\[
\boxed{\qquad\qquad\qquad\;
       +(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\!\left(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\right)
       +f\!\cdot\!\nabla\!\left(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\right)
     \Bigr]
    +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^{2}).}
\]

---

### Scaling of each retained term

Using the provided growth laws  
\(\|\nabla^k\log\rho_t\|=\Theta(e^{k\lambda t})\) with \(\lambda=-\lambda_{\min}>0\):

| term | symbolic form | dominant rate |
|------|---------------|---------------|
| \( -\nabla\!\cdot f\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{0}e^{0\lambda t})\) |
| \(-2(\nabla f):\nabla^{2}\log\rho_t\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| \(-\Delta(\nabla\!\cdot f)\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{0\lambda t})\) |
| \((\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\Delta\log\rho_t\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| \((\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{2\lambda t})\) |
| \((f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\,\Delta\log\rho_t\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{3\lambda t})\) |
| \((f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t)\,\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2}\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{3\lambda t})\) |
| \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla(\Delta\log\rho_t+\|\nabla\log\rho_t\|^{2})\) | Θ\((\varepsilon^{1}e^{3\lambda t})\) |

---

### Answer to the question

* **Do the \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho_t\) terms drop out?**  
  *Yes.*  In the material derivative they cancel at order \(\varepsilon^{0}\); what remains are only \(\varepsilon\)-suppressed composites whose scaling is at least \(\Theta(\varepsilon e^{2\lambda t})\), fully compliant with the relevance rules.

parts:
The exponential of the (positive-definite) Laplacian  
\[
e^{t\Delta}\;:\;D(\Delta)\subset L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n})\longrightarrow L^{2}(\mathbb R^{n}),\qquad t\ge 0,
\]  
is the strongly continuous **heat semigroup**.  Three equivalent “full” expansions are routinely used.

---

### 1. Power-series (Taylor / functional-calculus) expansion  
For any \(f\) in the domain of all powers of \(\Delta\) (e.g. Schwartz functions) the series converges absolutely in \(L^{2}\) and pointwise:

\[
\boxed{\;
e^{t\Delta}f \;=\;\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{k}}{k!}\,\Delta^{k}f.
\;}
\]

This is the definition coming directly from the functional calculus of the self-adjoint operator \(\Delta\).  Analyticity in \(t\) follows from the factorial denominator, and term-by-term differentiation reproduces \(\partial_{t}(e^{t\Delta})=\Delta e^{t\Delta}\).

---

### 2. Kernel (Gaussian convolution) expansion  
Via Fourier transform or fundamental solution one obtains

\[
(e^{t\Delta}f)(x)
=\frac{1}{(4\pi t)^{n/2}}\int_{\mathbb R^{n}}
\exp\!\Bigl(-\frac{|x-y|^{2}}{4t}\Bigr)\,f(y)\;dy,
\qquad t>0.
\]

Expanding the Gaussian around \(y=x\) and integrating successive moments of the normal distribution reproduces the power-series above (e.g. \(\int (y-x)^{2m} e^{-|y-x|^{2}/4t}\,dy =(2t)^{m}(2m-1)!!\)), so the two representations coincide.

---

### 3. Small-\(t\) heat-kernel (Minakshisundaram–Pleijel / Seeley–de Witt) asymptotic  
On a smooth Riemannian manifold \(M\) (or \(\mathbb R^{n}\) with potential terms added), the on-diagonal kernel has the short-time expansion

\[
e^{t\Delta}(x,x) \sim \frac{1}{(4\pi t)^{n/2}}
\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} a_{m}(x)\,t^{m},
\qquad t\downarrow 0,
\]

with \(a_{0}(x)=1\) and higher coefficients expressed recursively in curvature invariants (for \(\mathbb R^{n}\), \(a_{m}\equiv 0\) for \(m\ge 1\)).  Acting on a test function,
\[
(e^{t\Delta}f)(x)
\sim\frac{1}{(4\pi t)^{n/2}}\sum_{m=0}^{\infty} t^{m}
\int_{M} a_{m}(x,y)\,
e^{-\frac{d^{2}(x,y)}{4t}}\,f(y)\,dV_{y},
\]
which Borel-resums to the exact kernel and again reproduces the power-series when expanded around \(y=x\).

---

### Spectral expansion (for completeness)  
If \(-\Delta\) has a discrete spectrum \(\{\lambda_{j}\ge 0\}\) with orthonormal eigenfunctions \(\{\varphi_{j}\}\) (e.g. on a compact manifold with boundary conditions),

\[
e^{t\Delta}f
=\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} e^{-t\lambda_{j}}\,
\langle f,\varphi_{j}\rangle\,\varphi_{j},
\]
which is another exact representation equivalent to the previous two by the spectral theorem.

---

All four viewpoints are interchangeable; which one you call “the full expansion” depends on what you need to compute.  For purely local operator algebra (such as commutators with the Liouville operator) the **power-series in \(\Delta\)** is the most convenient, while for asymptotics or geometric analysis the **heat-kernel expansion** is standard.

phi = sp.Function('phi')(x,y)
f1 = sp.Function('f1')(x,y)
f2 = sp.Function('f2')(x,y)
# define delta operator
Delta_phi = sp.diff(phi,x,2)+sp.diff(phi,y,2)
# define Liouville operator on function: Lφ = -sp.diff(f1*phi,x) - sp.diff(f2*phi,y)
L_phi = - sp.diff(f1*phi, x) - sp.diff(f2*phi, y)
# compute Delta L phi
expr1 = sp.diff(L_phi, x,2) + sp.diff(L_phi, y,2)
# compute L Delta phi
expr2 = - sp.diff(f1*Delta_phi, x) - sp.diff(f2*Delta_phi, y)
comm = sp.simplify(expr1 - expr2)
comm

import sympy as sp
x,y=sp.symbols('x y')
phi=sp.Function('phi')(x,y)
f1=sp.Function('f1')(x,y)
f2=sp.Function('f2')(x,y)
def comm(phi):
    Delta_phi=sp.diff(phi,x,2)+sp.diff(phi,y,2)
    L_phi=- sp.diff(f1*phi,x) - sp.diff(f2*phi,y)
    expr1=sp.diff(L_phi,x,2)+sp.diff(L_phi,y,2)
    expr2=- sp.diff(f1*Delta_phi,x) - sp.diff(f2*Delta_phi,y)
    return sp.expand(expr1-expr2)
C=comm(phi)
C

[e^{\varepsilon \Delta}, \mathcal{L}_f] \rho = \int_0^{\varepsilon} e^{(\varepsilon-s)\Delta} S_f e^{s\Delta} \rho \, ds
\]

Where \( S_f \) is the differential operator:

\[
S_f g = - \Delta (\nabla \cdot f) g - 2 \nabla (\nabla \cdot f) \cdot \nabla g - (\Delta f) \cdot \nabla g - 2 (\nabla f) : \nabla^2 g
\]

We can also express this as a commutator expansion:

\[
[H_\varepsilon, \mathcal{L}_f] = \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{\varepsilon^k}{k!} ad_{\Delta}^k (\mathcal{L}_f)
\]

parts:
### Explicit operator kernel

Let  
\[
H_{\varepsilon}\;:=\;e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\qquad 
\mathcal L_{f}\rho\;:=\;-\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\,\rho\bigr),
\quad f\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb R^{n};\mathbb R^{n}).
\]

For any smooth scalar field \(g\),

\[
\boxed{\;
[\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]\,g
= -\bigl(\Delta\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr)g
  -2\;\nabla(\nabla\!\cdot f)\!\cdot\!\nabla g
  -\bigl(\Delta f\bigr)\!\cdot\!\nabla g
  -2\,(\nabla f):\nabla^{2}g\;}\tag{A}
\]

* \(\nabla f\) is the Jacobian \((\partial_{j}f_{i})\).  
* “\(:\)” denotes contraction: \((\nabla f):\nabla^{2}g=(\partial_{j}f_{i})\,\partial_{j}\partial_{i}g\).  
* \(\Delta f\) has components \(\Delta f_{i}\).  
* \(\nabla^{2}g\) is the Hessian of \(g\).

In index notation (summation over repeated indices),

\[
[\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]\,g
= -(\partial_{k}\partial_{k}\partial_{i}f_{i})\,g
  -2(\partial_{k}\partial_{i}f_{i})\,\partial_{k}g
  -(\partial_{k}\partial_{k}f_{i})\,\partial_{i}g
  -2(\partial_{k}f_{i})\,\partial_{k}\partial_{i}g. \tag{A'}
\]

---

### Full commutator with the heat semigroup

The Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff / Duhamel identity gives

\[
\boxed{\;
[H_{\varepsilon},\mathcal L_{f}]
=\int_{0}^{\varepsilon}
H_{\varepsilon-s}\,[\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]\,H_{s}\;ds\;}\tag{B}
\]

so acting on any \(g\),

\[
[H_{\varepsilon},\mathcal L_{f}]\,g
=\int_{0}^{\varepsilon}
e^{(\varepsilon-s)\Delta}
\bigl([\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]\,e^{s\Delta}g\bigr)\,ds,
\]
with the kernel \([\Delta,\mathcal L_{f}]\) from (A).

---

### Series expansion (nested commutators)

Equivalently,

\[
\boxed{\;
[H_{\varepsilon},\mathcal L_{f}]
=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\;
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_{f}),\quad
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(X)
=[\Delta,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m-1}(X)],\;
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{0}(X)=X\;.}\tag{C}
\]

---

The combination of (A) with either (B) or (C) provides the complete, closed-form expression for the commutator \([e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_{f}]\) for all \(\varepsilon>0\).

parts:
Below I write the first three nested commutators  
\(\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_f):=[\underbrace{\Delta,\,[\Delta,\dots[\Delta}_{m\text{ times}},\mathcal L_f]\dots]]\)  
in a compact tensor/index form.  They act on a test function \(g\in C^{\infty}(\mathbb R^{n})\).

---

### Notation
* \(\partial_i:=\tfrac{\partial}{\partial x_i}\), \(\Delta=\partial_k\partial_k\).
* Summation over repeated indices is assumed.
* \(\nabla^2 g\) is the Hessian, \(\nabla^3 g\) the third-order derivative tensor, etc.

---

### \(m=1\)

\[
\boxed{\;
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{1}(\mathcal L_f)\,g
=-\bigl(\partial_k\partial_k\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,g
-2\bigl(\partial_k\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,\partial_k g
-\bigl(\partial_k\partial_k f_i\bigr)\,\partial_i g
-2\bigl(\partial_k f_i\bigr)\,\partial_k\partial_i g
\;}
\tag{1}
\]

---

### \(m=2\)

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{2}(\mathcal L_f)\,g
={}&-\bigl(\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_\ell\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,g \\
&-4\bigl(\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,\partial_\ell g \\
&-\Bigl(\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_\ell f_i
        +4\,\partial_k\partial_k\partial_i\partial_\ell f_\ell\Bigr)\,\partial_i g \\
&-4\bigl(\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell f_i\bigr)\,\partial_\ell\partial_i g \\
&-8\bigl(\partial_k\partial_\ell f_i\bigr)\,\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_i g
\end{aligned}
\;}
\tag{2}
\]

---

### \(m=3\)

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{3}(\mathcal L_f)\,g
={}&-\bigl(\partial_m\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_\ell\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,g \\
&-6\bigl(\partial_m\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_i f_i\bigr)\,\partial_\ell g \\
&-\Bigl(\partial_m\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_\ell f_i
        +6\,\partial_m\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_i\partial_\ell f_\ell\Bigr)\,\partial_i g \\
&-6\bigl(\partial_m\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell f_i\bigr)\,\partial_\ell\partial_i g \\
&-18\bigl(\partial_m\partial_k\partial_k\partial_\ell f_i\bigr)\,\partial_m\partial_\ell\partial_i g \\
&-12\bigl(\partial_m\partial_k\partial_\ell f_i\bigr)\,\partial_m\partial_k\partial_\ell\partial_i g
\end{aligned}
\;}
\tag{3}
\]

---

### How the pattern emerges  
At each step:

1. **Scalar term** gains two extra Laplacians on \(\nabla\!\cdot\!f\).  
2. **Vector-gradient term** gains one Laplacian plus one extra spatial derivative, with binomial-type coefficients (\(2,4,6,\dots\)).  
3. **Higher-rank terms** shift one derivative from coefficients to the test-function derivatives; their combinatorial factors follow Pascal-triangle rows multiplied by powers of 2.

Hence every further iteration simply appends two additional spatial derivatives to all coefficients while redistributing them among the operator’s derivative orders in the same combinatorial way.

parts:
Yes—after every further commutator one very specific structure re-appears:

---

### Compact tensor form  
Let  

* \(D^{m}f\;\equiv\;\partial_{\alpha_{1}}\!\cdots\!\partial_{\alpha_{m}}f_{i}\) (m-th symmetric derivative tensor of \(f\)),  
* \(D^{m+1}g\;\equiv\;\partial_{\alpha_{1}}\!\cdots\!\partial_{\alpha_{m}}\partial_{i}g\).

Indices \(\alpha_{1},\dots ,\alpha_{m},i\) are summed.  
Then for every \(m\ge 1\)

\[
\boxed{\;
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_{f})\,g
\;\supset\;
(-2)^{m}\, D^{m}f : D^{m+1}g
\;}
\tag{★}
\]

where “\(:\)” denotes full index contraction.

---

### What the pattern says

* **Derivative order on \(g\)** rises linearly: \(m+1\).
* **Derivative order on \(f\)** is always one lower: \(m\).
* **Numeric factor** doubles each step and keeps the same sign, giving \((-2)^{m}\).

---

### Why it happens  

Start the induction with  
\[
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{1}(\mathcal L_{f})\,g
=\;-2\,(\partial_{\alpha}f_{i})\,\partial_{\alpha}\partial_{i}g .
\]

Assume (★) holds for \(m\).  
Compute \(\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m+1}=[\Delta,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}]\).  
Writing \(\Delta=\partial_{p}\partial_{p}\) and using the product rule,

\[
[\Delta,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}]\,g
=2\,(-2)^{m}\,(\partial_{p}D^{m}f)\,(\partial_{p}D^{m+1}g)+\dots
=-2^{\,m+1}\,D^{m+1}f : D^{m+2}g+\dots
\]

The terms displayed are exactly the new highest-order pair; everything with fewer derivatives on \(g\) is collected in “\(\dots\)”. The factor 2 comes from the two ways the Laplacian’s derivatives can split between the coefficient and the argument, so the coefficient doubles at each step.

Thus the pattern (★) holds for all \(m\).

---

### Read-off rule  

> **After \(m\) nested commutators, the unique term carrying the maximal \((m\!+\!1)\)-fold derivative of the test function is always**  
> \[
> (-2)^{m}\;(\nabla^{m}f)\cdot\nabla^{m+1}g,
> \]  
> with every index of the \(m\)-th derivative of \(f\) paired with the corresponding index in the \((m\!+\!1)\)-th derivative of \(g\).

That is the complete and systematic pattern for the “top-derivative-on-\(g\)” contribution.

The operator can be defined using a sum of derivatives, but the highest derivative terms arise when considering the transport part. The key takeaway is that this operator has a known form in PDE literature, where it's referred to as the "mollified transport commutator," frequently used in commutator estimates for equations like Navier-Stokes.

parts:
Yes. The whole tower of brackets you just computed is nothing more than the **Heisenberg‐type conjugation of the transport operator by the heat semigroup**.  There are two equivalent “closed‐form’’ ways to see it.

---

## 1 Conjugation formula (operator exponential in the Heisenberg picture)

Write the adjoint action of the Laplacian as  
\[
\operatorname{Ad}_{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}}(X)
:=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\,X\,e^{-\varepsilon\Delta}.
\]
Because \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) is an exponential,  
\[
\operatorname{Ad}_{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}}(X)
=\exp\!\bigl(\varepsilon\,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}\bigr)X,
\qquad
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}(X):=[\Delta,X].
\]

Taking \(X=\mathcal L_{f}\), we get  
\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_{f}e^{-\varepsilon\Delta}
=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\frac{\varepsilon^{m}}{m!}\,
\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}^{m}(\mathcal L_{f}).
\]

Hence the commutator you are interested in is simply the *increment* of this similarity transform:
\[
\boxed{\;
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_{f}]
=\bigl(\operatorname{Ad}_{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}}-1\bigr)\mathcal L_{f}
=\bigl(e^{\varepsilon\,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}}-1\bigr)\mathcal L_{f}.
\;}
\]

In other words, the series you wrote for the top‐derivative terms is just the
Taylor expansion of \(\exp(\varepsilon\,\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta})\) acting on
\(\mathcal L_{f}\).

---

## 2 Phase–space (symbol) picture — an exact shift operator

Identify differential operators with their Weyl symbols:
\[
\Delta \;\longleftrightarrow\;|\xi|^{2},\qquad
\mathcal L_{f}\;\longleftrightarrow\;a(x,\xi):=i\,f(x)\!\cdot\!\xi
            \;+\;\text{lower order}.
\]

Egorov’s theorem says that conjugation by \(e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\) transports the symbol along the **Hamiltonian flow** generated by \(|\xi|^{2}\):
\[
\Phi_{t}:(x,\xi)\mapsto\bigl(x+2t\,\xi,\;\xi\bigr).
\]

Therefore  
\[
e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_{f}e^{-\varepsilon\Delta}
\;\;\widehat{=}\;\;
a\!\circ\!\Phi_{\,\varepsilon}(x,\xi)
      = i\,f\bigl(x+2\varepsilon\xi\bigr)\!\cdot\!\xi + \dots
\]

Subtracting the original \(a(x,\xi)\) gives
\[
[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_{f}]
\;\;\widehat{=}\;\;
i\,\bigl[f(x+2\varepsilon\xi)-f(x)\bigr]\!\cdot\!\xi + \dots
\]

Expanding \(f(x+2\varepsilon\xi)\) in a Taylor series,
\[
f_{i}(x+2\varepsilon\xi)
=\sum_{m=0}^{\infty}\frac{(2\varepsilon)^{m}}{m!}
         (\xi\!\cdot\!\nabla)^{m}f_{i}(x),
\]
and quantising term-by-term reproduces exactly the pattern you observed:
\[
(-2)^{m}\,(\nabla^{m}f_{i})\,\nabla^{m+1}_{\,i}g
\quad\text{at stage }m.
\]

So the “mysterious’’ operator with the maximal \((m\!+\!1)\)-fold derivative on \(g\) is nothing but the \(m\)-th term in the expansion of
\[
\boxed{\;
\mathcal T_{\varepsilon}:=\operatorname{Ad}_{e^{\varepsilon\Delta}}(\mathcal L_{f})
      =\mathrm{Op}\bigl[f(x+2\varepsilon\xi)\cdot\xi\bigr]+(\text{lower order}),
\;}
\]
and the commutator is \(\mathcal T_{\varepsilon}-\mathcal L_{f}\).

---

### Relation to known PDE literature  

* In harmonic‐analysis language this is the classical **mollifier–transport commutator**  
  \([J_{\varepsilon},f\!\cdot\!\nabla]\) with \(J_{\varepsilon}=e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\).  
  It lies at the heart of the Constantin–E–Titi commutator estimate and many Onsager‐type regularity proofs.

* In semiclassical / microlocal analysis it is the **Egorov transform** of \(f\!\cdot\!\nabla\) by the free Schrödinger flow, i.e. conjugation by the metaplectic operator generated by \(|\xi|^{2}\).

Thus the entire infinite ladder of highest-derivative terms you computed is just the Taylor expansion of a perfectly well-defined conjugated operator; no further “new’’ operator exponential is required beyond the similarity transform \(e^{\varepsilon\operatorname{ad}_{\Delta}}\).

The user wants me to calculate the time derivative of i, defined as i = \log e^{\varepsilon \Delta} \rho(x,t), using commutators, where ρ is advected by the Liouville equation with drift f.

First, I recognize that ρ obeys the equation ∂_t ρ = - ∇·(f ρ), or - L_f ρ. The smoothing operator e^{\varepsilon \Delta} commutes with Δ but not L_f. So, I set i = log(ρ_ε), where ρ_ε = e^{εΔ} ρ and compute ∂_t i using the commutator.

I’m refining the expression for ∂_t ρ_ε. First, I know that ∂_t ρ_ε = - A L_f A^{-1} ρ_ε. So, ∂_t i becomes -(A L_f A^{-1} ρ_ε)/ρ_ε. The goal is to work in commutator form, so I adjust to include [A, L_f] A^{-1}. L_f ρ_ε/ρ_ε simplifies into terms involving the drift f and spatial derivatives. After reconsidering the Liouville operator, I'll define it as acting on ρ as - f·∇ ρ - (∇· f) ρ.

To calculate ∂_t i in commutator form, I start by expressing ∂_t ρ_ε = e^{εΔ} ∂_t ρ and using the Liouville operator. I can introduce the commutator to get the expanded form: ∂_t i = ( \mathcal{L}_f \log ρ_ε + [e^{εΔ}, \mathcal{L}_f] ρ ) / ρ_ε. For first-order expansion, the commutator of e^{εΔ} and \mathcal{L}_f approximates to ε [Δ, \mathcal{L}_f] + O(ε²). After careful steps, I derive the formula for [Δ, f·∇], reaching a more manageable expression to continue my work.

The goal now is to compute the time derivative of \( i \), given user input and context. Starting from the Liouville equation, I break it down. I’ll use the commutator identity and derive the time derivative using \( \mathcal{L}_f \). I’ll also present the step-by-step derivation, starting from \( \mathcal{L}_f = -f \cdot \nabla \) and work my way through to the final equation with the commutator representation. parts:
Write the Gaussian-smoothed density

\[
\rho_\varepsilon(x,t)\;:=\;e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho(x,t),\qquad 
i(x,t;\varepsilon)\;:=\;\log\rho_\varepsilon(x,t).
\]

---

### 1.  Time derivative in commutator form  

Because \(\rho\) obeys the Liouville equation  
\[
\partial_t\rho \;=\;-\nabla\!\cdot\!\bigl(f\,\rho\bigr)\;=\;\mathcal L_f\rho,
\qquad 
\mathcal L_f:=-\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla-\bigl(\nabla\!\cdot f\bigr),
\]
one gets

\[
\partial_t\rho_\varepsilon
   =e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\mathcal L_f\rho
   =\mathcal L_f e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho
    +\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho
   =\mathcal L_f\rho_\varepsilon
    +\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho .
\]

Divide by \(\rho_\varepsilon\) to obtain

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t i
   =\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
    +\frac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho}
           {\rho_\varepsilon}\;}
\tag{A}
\]

---

### 2.  Isolate the convective part  

Since \(\mathcal L_f\rho_\varepsilon
      =-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\rho_\varepsilon
       -(\nabla\!\cdot f)\,\rho_\varepsilon\),

\[
\frac{\mathcal L_f\rho_\varepsilon}{\rho_\varepsilon}
      =-\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla i-\nabla\!\cdot f .
\]

Hence

\[
\boxed{\;
\partial_t i
   =-\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla i
     -\nabla\!\cdot f
     +\frac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho}
            {\rho_\varepsilon}\;}
\tag{B}
\]

or, equivalently, for the material derivative \(D/Dt=\partial_t+f\!\cdot\!\nabla\),

\[
\boxed{\;
\frac{D i}{D t}
   =-\,\nabla\!\cdot f
     +\frac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho}
            {\rho_\varepsilon}\;.}
\tag{C}
\]

---

### 3.  Small-\(\varepsilon\) expansion of the commutator  

Using the Baker–Campbell–Hausdorff series,

\[
\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]
   =\varepsilon\,[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]
    +\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2!}\,[\Delta,[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]]
    +\cdots .
\]

To first order,

\[
\partial_t i
   =-\,f\!\cdot\!\nabla i
     -\nabla\!\cdot f
     +\varepsilon\,\frac{[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\rho}{\rho}
     +\mathcal O(\varepsilon^{2}),
\qquad
\rho_\varepsilon\to\rho\;\text{as}\;\varepsilon\to0.
\]

---

### 4.  Leading commutator \([\Delta,\mathcal L_f]\)

With \(\mathcal L_f=-f\!\cdot\!\nabla-\nabla\!\cdot f\),

\[
[\Delta,\mathcal L_f]g
   =-(\Delta f)\!\cdot\!\nabla g
     -2(\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla g
     -(\Delta\nabla\!\cdot f)\,g,
\]
where \((\nabla f)^{\!\top}\!:\nabla\nabla g
      =\sum_{i,j}\partial_i f_j\,\partial_{ij}g\).

Plugging this into (B) or (C) gives the explicit first-order correction coming from diffusion not commuting with advection.

---

### 5.  Limits  

* **Perfect resolution** (\(\varepsilon\to0\))  
  \(\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]=\mathcal O(\varepsilon)\),  
  so (B) reduces to the unsmoothed identity  
  \(\partial_t\log\rho
     =-f\!\cdot\!\nabla\log\rho-\nabla\!\cdot f\).

* **Inviscid advection** (\(f\) divergence-free)  
  \(\nabla\!\cdot f=0\), whence  
  \(\frac{D i}{D t}
     =\dfrac{\bigl[e^{\varepsilon\Delta},\mathcal L_f\bigr]\rho}
            {\rho_\varepsilon}\);  
  all change in the smoothed log-density is generated purely by the commutator.

Equations (B) and (C) thus give the exact time evolution of \(i=\log e^{\varepsilon\Delta}\rho\) in terms of the non-commutativity between Gaussian smoothing and Liouville advection.
